Joined service at the age of sixteen in 1956 in Indian Bureau of Mines as a daily rated workman; worked in N.C.D.C. for a brief period of six months; joined Durgapur Steel Plant, (erstwhile H.S.L.) in the year 1958; one of the Founders of Hindustan Steel Employees Union, Durgapur, the largest Trade Union under C.I.T.U. and became its Secretary at the age of twenty; joined undivided Communist Party in the year 1961; shifted to C.P.I. (M) when the party was split in 1964; detained without trial once in 1968 and for a year during 1970-71; imprisoned for a number of times between 1968 and 1972; played a leading role in forming trade unions in a number of Steel Plants spread over the country; founded the Steel Workers Federation of India in 1980 and became its General Secretary till shifting to Delhi to take charge as National Secretary of C.I.T.U. in 1989; resigned from Steel Authority of India Limited in 1989 after rendering 32 years of service to Durgapur Steel Plant; represented Indian Trade Union in the International Conference on 150th anniversary of writing of the Communist Manifesto by Karl Marx, Paris, 13-16 May 1998

Took active part in political and social activities since student days; thirty years continuous career as Member, Maharashtra Legislative Council and retired on 27 July 1994; pioneer work done in association with Shri V.P. Naik, the then Chief Minister, Maharashtra and Shri V.S. Page, the then Chairman, Maharashtra Legislative Council in introducing Employment Guarantee Scheme in Maharashtra State in 1975; President, Republican Party of India; Vice-President, (i) World Fellowship of Buddhists - elected unanimously in the Meeting of the Central General Council of the World Fellowship of Buddhists at Bangkok on 23 November 1980 and (ii) World Fellowship of Buddhists, re-elected in 1998; was Chairman, (i) Sub-Committee of State Board of Religious and Linguistic Minorities, Maharashtra and (ii) Reception Committee of the 62nd All India Marathi Sahitya Sammelan held at Amravati (Maharashtra) from 21-23 January 1989; Chairman, (i) Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Smarak Samiti, Deeksha Bhoomi, Nagpur and (ii) Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Shikshan Prasarak Mandal, Amravati; Nominated, (i) Vice-President of State Level Committee on Dr. B.R. Ambedkar's Writings and Speeches (Maharashtra) and (ii) Member of the State Level Peace Committee for maintaining peace and harmony in the State, particularly in Bombay after communal riots, which was formed under the Presidentship of the Governor of Maharashtra; was Member, (i) Birth Centenary Celebration Committee of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar under the Presidentship of the then Prime Minister Shri V.P. Singh, Shri Chandra Shekhar and Shri P.V. Narasimha Rao, (ii) Standing Committee of the National Celebration of Birth Centenary of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar for maintaining Unity and Integrity of the Nation under the Chairmanship of the then Prime Minister Shri Narasimha Rao and (iii) Land Reforms Committee, Government of India; Executive Member, Buddha's Life International Association, Head Quarters in Taiwan and Los Angeles (U.S.A.); attended, (i) the 15th Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference held at Trinidad and Tobago, 1969, (ii) 20th Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference held at Colombo (Sri Lanka), 1974, (iii) the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference at Lusaka (Zambia), 1980, (iv) as a delegate, the First Asian Conference on Population and Development held at Beijing (China) in October-November 1981, (v) as a delegate, the Asian Peace Conference held at Moscow (U.S.S.R.) and Mongolia in September 1984, (vi) 13 to 19 General Conferences of the World Fellowship of Buddhists held at Bangkok(Thailand), Colombo(Sri Lanka), August 1984, Kathmandu (Nepal), November 1986, Los Angeles(U.S.A.), November 1988, Seoul (South Korea), October 1990, Taiwan, October-November 1992 and again at Bangkok, November 1994 and (vii) Executive Council Meeting of World Fellowship of Buddhists, Bangkok, March 1988 and Kyoto (Japan), August 1989, Australia, 1998 and Nepal, 1999; represented, the Maharashtra Branch of Parliamentary Association at the Anniversary Celebration of Parliament of Bahamas at Nasau, September 1970; visited, (i) U.S.S.R., as a delegate of Indo-Soviet Cultural Society, participated in the celebrations of the 5th Anniversary of the Indo-Soviet Treaty and the Month of Friendship and Solidarity with India, observed by the Indo-Soviet Friendship Society in U.S.S.R., July-August 1976, (ii) U.S.A., to study the electoral process of Presidential Election in America,1980, (iii) North Korea, as a delegate of the Indo-Korean Friendship Association, October-November 1986 and (iv) Malaysia, in a delegation with the President of India, 2001; submitted, reports to the Government of Maharashtra on important subjects: (i) Report of the Study Team on Leprosy, Maharashtra, (ii) Report of the Committee to probe into malpractices and irregularities under the Employment Guarantee Scheme, Maharashtra and (iii) Report on Riots

A true follower of Gandhi, Nehru and Vinobaji; participated in the Freedom Struggle; established Parja Mandal in erstwhile Jind State in pre-independence period; launched agitation for establishment of a responsible Government in Jind State and was imprisoned several times; waged struggle against the practice of untouchability and got Harijans the right to enter temples and use wells in his area; undertook several padyatras, collected thousands of acres of land and distributed it among the landless during the Bhoodan Movement and became Vinobaji's trusted sewak; fought against social evils like dowry system, child marriage and stood for widow remarriage; started the tradition of community-marriages without dowry; worked for spreading education by upgrading existing schools/colleges and opening new ones; Chief Patron, All India Vaish Federation; Patron, Maharaj Agrasen Medical Education & Scientific Research Society, Haryana; Trustee, Vaish Mahavidyalaya Trust which runs (i) Vaish Senior Secondary School and (ii) Vaish Model School; Trustee and Member, Haryana Prakritik Chikitsalaya; President, Managing Committee, (i) Vaish P.G. As a student, took part in all freedom movements initiated by Mahatma Gandhi; took active part in the Quit India Movement; attended the Congress Session in Bombay, August 1942; was associated with the underground socialist leader Shri S.M.Joshi, Shri Ashok Mehta and Shrimati Aruna Asaf Ali; played active role in the publication of the Congress News Bulletin and broadcasting news through Azad Radio in Bombay; Founder Member, Students Federation of India in Delhi; distinguished himself as a scientist and researcher in the fields of Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry; has been engaged in education for over 35 years dealing with the problems of Higher Education, specially in the field of science and technology, research, education technology, non-formal method of education and vocational courses for women; played an important role in reviving and developing, (i) the Nav Nalanda Mahavihara as an international centre for advanced studies in Pali language and Buddhist studies, (ii) Institute of Prakrit and Jainology at Vaishali, and (iii) the historic areas of Vaishali, Nalanda and the International Buddhist Enclave at Bodh Gaya, as part of the "Buddhist Circuit" for tourists and pilgrims visiting Bihar; made efforts to modernise Madarasas Education by integrating them with modern education and technical training; awarded, Honorary Doctorate, Vidya Vajaspati by the Institute of Tibetan Studies in 1997 in recognition of his contribution to Buddhist studies; initiated special schemes and projects for employment generation for the educated unemployed in urban centres and rural employment through integrated farming and self-employment schemes in Bihar; re-organised the Red Cross Society to provide for, (i) polyclinics for free medical advice and treatment to the poor; As a committed social activist and inspired by the fiery zeal of her father, has worked extensively for construction labourers and undertook a five-day hunger strike for the slum dwellers in Mumbai; committed to the cause of slum dwellers in Mumbai and as Chairperson of the Nivara Hakk Suraksha Samiti, managed to get alternative land for the disputed slum dwellers of Sanjay Gandhi Nagar; has participated in several street plays and demonstrations against communalism; undertook a four day march for communal harmony from Delhi to Meerut in April, 1989 along with Swami Agnivesh and Asghar Ali Engineer; in the aftermath of the Babri Masjid demolition, along with activists of Nivara Hakk, helped to diffuse tension in several slums and to their credit, Nivara Hakk did not have a single incident of violence while the city was ablaze; raised funds for displaced Kashmiri migrants and the victims of Latur earthquake with the extensive tour of her play "Tumhari Amrita"; has acted in more than hundred Hindi films (both mainstream and parallel cinema); Satyajit Ray, the noted film-maker, in his book, Our films, Their films, has said: 'Shabana Azmi in her very first film "Ankur" firmly establishes herself as the finest dramatic actress of the country'; has had retrospectives of her films at the prestigious George Pompidou Centre, Paris, the Norwegian Film Institute, the Smithsonian Institution, the American Film Institute, Washington, Pacific Cinematheque and Winnipeg Cinematheque; has won international acclaim in films especially John Schlesinger's "Madame Sousatzka", co-starring Shirley Mc Laine, Nicholas Klotz's "The Bengali Night", co-starring John Hurt and Hugh Grant, Roland Joffe's "City of Joy", co-starring Patrick Swayze, Channel 4's "Immaculate Conception" opposite James Wilby, Blake Edward's "The Son of Pink Panther" and Ismail Merchant's "In Custody"; Awarded with (i) Gold Medal for the Best Student in Acting by the Film and Television Institute of India, Pune, (ii) National Award for the Best Actress for her first film "Ankur" in 1974, "Arth" in 1983, "Khandhar" in 1984, "Paar" in 1985 and "God Mother" in 1999 (the only actor/actress to achieve this feat in the country), (iii) Padmashri, 1988, (iv) Film Fare Award, (v) Rajiv Gandhi Award for "Excellence in Secularism", August, 1994, (vi) B.F.J.A. Award, (vii) Yash Bhartiya Award by the Government of Uttar Pradesh for highlighting women's issues in her work as an actress and activist and (viii) King Chavez Parks Award, 2002; also won the International Award for Best Actress for Gulzar's "Libaas" in North Korea in 1993, for Gautam Ghose's "Patang" at the Taormina Arte Festival in Italy in August 1994, for Deepa Mehta's "Fire" at the Chicago International Film Festival and at the Los Angeles Outfest in 1996; housing for the underprivileged, welfare of women and children and issues of secularism

Political and related activities: Firm believer in the concept of Swadeshi and the spiritual and cultural values of Hindutva; known for his views on the onslaught of foreign multinationals; vigorously undertook the campaign against foreign infiltrators and the ISI; had demanded that India should go nuclear; raised several issues of public interest in Parliament including the drinking water problem, trade in human organs, share scam, rising foreign debt; a strong advocate of a modern, strong and 'debt free India'; was Incharge of Youth Wing of B.J.S.; arrested, in 1948 for offering Satyagraha for removing ban on R.S.S. and later participated in several B.J.S. movements and jailed several times; detained under M.I.S.A. during Emergency, 26 June 1975 to March 1977; as President of B.J.P., undertook Ekta Yatra from Kanyakumari to Srinagar and hoisted National Flag at Lal Chowk, Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir on the Republic Day, 1992 and, was arrested on 8 December 1992 after the incidents in Ayodhya on 6 December 1992 and detained at Mata Tila and re-arrested in December 1993 and detained at Pipri Participation in International Conferences: Participated in Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) Conference in 1977; addressed, (i) several conferences on Swadeshi throughout the country, (ii) the European Hindu Conference held at Frankfurt, Germany, 1991, (iii) Global Vision 2000 International Conference held in U.S.A., (iv) International Youth Conference held at Chicago in 1993 to mark 100th Anniversary of Swami Vivekanand's Address to the Parliament of Religions, (v) International Seminar on Science and Religion held at Washington in 1993, (vi) Vishwa Hindu Mahasangh Conference at Varanasi in 1993, (vii) World Hindu Conference in Durban, South Africa in 1995, (viii) European Science Congress, 2002, (ix) European Research Council at Brussels in 2002 and (x) Commonwealth Science Council Ministerial Gathering at South Africa in June, 2002; delivered lectures on, (i) Physics and Indian Philosophy in Durban in 1995, (ii) Cultural Policies for Development at the International Governmental Conference at Stockholm, 1988, (his address was read), (iii) Second Parliament of Science, Religion and Philosophy at the World Philosopher Meet on Science, Spirituality and Development at Geneva, 1988, (iv) Science and Religion in Frankfurt, Germany, 1991, (v) 8th Bose - Einstein Lecture on Science, Technology and Environment in 1998, (vi) Sustainable Consumption at Bonn University, Germany; St. Petersburg, 2000; Brazil Academy of Science, Rio-de-Janerio, 2000-2001, (vii) UNESCO Conference, Paris and (viii) World Conference on Science at Budapest; led Indian delegation to, (i) G-77 Conference, Cuba, (ii) UN Conference on Women, UNO and (iii) UN Summit on Children, New York, 2002; Presided, (i) UNESCO Sponsored International Conference on 'Dialogue Among Civilizations' held at Delhi from 9 to 11 July 2003, (ii) UNESCO Conference on 'Education For All - 2003', held in New Delhi, (iii) Third World Academy Conference, New Delhi, (iv) Climate Change Conference, New Delhi and (v) International Conference on Mapping, Bangkok; represented India at Global Dharma Conference at New Jersey, USA in 2003 to mark the 100th anniversary of the Mahasamadhi of Swami Vivekananda; represented India at the UNESCO Conferences held in China, Paris and Egypt (Bioethics); delivered a keynote address in World Sanskrit Conference, Bangkok; addressed Commonwealth Science Council Ministerial Gathering at South Africa, June 2002; has the distinction of being the first Indian Minister to address the European Science Congress at Brussels in 2002 Awards and Honours: Awarded, (i) Jawaharlal Nehru Award by the Indian Science Conference, 1999, (ii) Nicolay Rerikh Medal for his contribution in the sphere of Ecology by the International Academy of Ecology, Man and Nature Protection Sciences, St. Petersburg, (iii) National Citizens Award, 2001, (iv) Friendship Medal by the President of Mongolia in July, 2002 for his contribution towards development of relationship between India and Mongolia and (v) Life Time Award by the Indian Science Congress, 2004; conferred, (i) degree of D.Sc. (Honoris Causa) by the Universities of Kanpur, Gorakhpur, Banaras and Kurukshetra and (ii) degree of Mahamahopadhyay by Tirupati Sanskrit Vidyapeetha (Deemed University) and by Sampurnand Sanskrit Vidyapeetha; Fellow, Vigyan Parishad and was honoured by the National Academy of Science (India) as an external fellow; was elected fellow of Russian National Academy of Natural Sciences in 2001 whose membership includes world famous scientists and nobel laureats; his biographical summary was published in the Encyclopedia of the Academy; elected as Honorary Academician on Ecology Section by International Academy of Ecology, Man and Nature Protection Sciences, Russian Federation; was Convenor, Forum of Parliamentarians on TRIPPS and GATT; an advocate of sublime Indian values and ancient scientific knowledge; scientific temper, development of science and technology and their applications for removal of poverty; protagonist of holistic view of science and philosophy; his main interest is the study of science and universal consciousness, integral humanism and holistic values of life in the present world; proponent of sustainable consumption, an idea which has become a live issue in the world

led, a Satyagraha on Indo-Tibet border, 1997; organised and participated in conferences, seminars and marches for the cause of Tibet and to support the non-violent movement for democracy in Myanmar; President, (i) Indo-Pak Soldiers' Inititiative for Peace (I.P.S.I.P.), both of India and Pakistan, (ii) Rashtriya Seva Samithi (R.A.S.S.), Tirupati, (iii) Hanuman Vyayam Prasarak Mandal (H.V.M.P.), Amravati (Maharashtra), the oldest organization of physical education and sports which has trained over fifty thousand youths of all the States of India and (iv) Vinoba Janamsthan Pratishthan Trust; Joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (R.S.S.) in 1940; participated in the freedom struggle; played an important role in the students' movement while studying in the Maheshwari School in 1942 and took part in the distribution of secret pamphlets published by Indore Prajamandal in his early student life; endured punishment in the school for voicing the slogan of Vande Mataram during the freedom struggle; Pracharak, R.S.S. in 1948; sentenced for four months and was imprisoned in the jails of Indore and Ratlam from 1948 to 1949 for observing Satyagraha to demand lifting of the ban on the R.S.S.; was arrested with late Shri Eknathji Ranade; participated in the Kashmir Movement in 1953 on the call given by Dr. Shyama Prasad Mookerjee and imprisoned in Kathua and Jammu jails; joined Jana Sangh in 1964; was arrested during the Emergency in 1975 but escaped from the custody and remained underground for 19 months; led the Lok Sangarsh Samiti in Madhya Pradesh established by Lok Nayak Jai Prakash Narain during the Emergency; launched a prolonged movement called "Gram Raj Abhiyan" and mobilized thousands of activists in Madhya Pradesh in 1988 which helped in the election victory of the B.J.P. in the State in 1990; made special efforts to integrate the tribals and Harijans with the B.J.P. and launched a movement to redress their problems; went on a week-long hunger strike to redress farmers' problems and was successful in having the region declared as 'drought affected' in 1988; Organising Secretary, Bharatiya Jana Sangh, Madhya Pradesh, 1972-77; State General Secretary, (i) Janata Party, Madhya Pradesh, 1977-80 and (ii) Bharatiya Janata Party, Madhya Pradesh, 1980-82; All India Secretary, B.J.P., 1999; National General Secretary, B.J.P., 2002; National Vice-President, B.J.P, 2003 - 2005; Founder Member, (i) Bhopal Deen Dayal Vichar Prakashan in the memory of late Pandit Deen Dayalji and (ii) Chairvaiti, a weekly magazine, Bhopal; Incharge, B.J.P., (i) Haryana, 1993, (ii) Orissa and Assam, 1996, (iii) Uttar Pradesh, 2000 and (iv) North-eastern States, 2003; Patron of many social organisations

designated as Senior Advocate by the Madras High Court in July 2000; participated in (i) 'Criminal Advocacy Workshops' in 1981 and 1989 and (ii) 'Workshop on Constitutional Law' at Bangalore in 1997, conducted by the Bar Council of India Trust under its continuing education programme; presented papers at the State level Conferences of the Public Prosecutors; delivered (i) lectures in the refresher courses conducted by the Prosecution Departments of the States of Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Karnataka, 1997-2000 and (ii) guest lecture in the Department of Law, University of Wales, United Kingdom in November 1999, on invitation; regularly giving lectures for the last five years as an Honorary Lecturer in the Judicial Academy at Chennai since its inception, during the training programmes for subordinate judicial officers; visited, (i) U.K. in 1992 as a scholar sponsored by the British Council to study the 'Developments in Criminal Law in Britain' and attended court works at the Old Bailey Central London Criminal Courts, Croydon Crown Court and Royal Courts of Justice, London, gained work experience at the Crown Prosecution Department, Manchester and studied the investigation procedures adopted in Irish terrorist acts, observed the working system of the legal aid and probation systems in Great Britain, and was invited to discuss about the then newly introduced Criminal Justice Act, 1992 by the Home Office, London, (ii) Malaysia and Australia in 1998 to study the Criminal Court procedures in those countries and interacted with the Members of Judiciary, Prosecutors and Defence Attorneys , (iii) Australia and U. Professor of Hindi Literature, Magadh University, Bihar, 1973-75; an academician by profession, he became involved in social service inspired by the spirit of the Antyodaya Yojana, a unique programme launched by Shri Bhairon Singh Shekhawat, the then Chief Minister of Rajasthan in 1978 and inaugurated by the then President of India, Shri Neelam Sanjiva Reddy in his own village Manaklao; a persuasive leader, a successful motivator and a great mobiliser of the masses, he has aroused and sensitized the rural community in the State of Rajasthan about the seriousness of the problems of opium consumption and its deleterious impact on the health, productivity and welfare of the people; has organized scientific campaigns against opium consumption through pragmatic approach and worked with a crusading zeal to rehabilitate the de-addicted persons through various innovative capacity building measures; pioneered the institutionalised efforts for preventing drug abuse in the country which serves as the role model for others in this field; as a dedicated social worker, he has championed the cause of the weaker sections of the society, especially people with disabilities in the rural areas; has endeavoured to undertake several measures for the rehabilitation, development and welfare of the disabled; Founder President and Patron of the Federation of Indian NGO Drug Abuse Prevention, New Delhi, a National Forum of NGO recognized by the Government of India; Founder Manager, Brigadier Zabar Singh Public School, Jodhpur; Founder, (i) Veer Durgadas Hostel, Pali, Marwar, Rajasthan, (ii) Maharaja Prahlad Singh Charitable Trust, Jodhpur and (iii) Kundleshwari Paryavaran Vikas Sansthan, Manaklao; President, (i) Raghuvansh Balika Vidhyapeeth, Jodhpur and (ii) Sucheta Kriplani Rural Development Centre, Village Newara, Distt. Jodhpur; Organising Secretary, Chopasni Shiksha Samiti, Jodhpur; Elected Sarpanch, Manaklao Gram Panchayat, Manaklao; Member, (i) Combined Advisory Committee on Social Welfare Research for the Ministry of Welfare, Government of India, (ii) Syndicate of Jai Narayan Vyas University, Jodhpur, 1991-97, (iii) Advisory Committee for All India Radio, Jodhpur, (iv) Advisory Committee for Adult Education, Jodhpur and (v) Regional Telecommunications Advisory Committee, Jodhpur; Sitting Member, Rajasthan High Court Lok Adalat, Jodhpur Accomplishments : Drug Abuse Prevention: Launched the Opium De-addiction, Treatment, Training and Research Trust in 1979; conducted nearly 700 drug de-addiction mobile camps benefiting over sixty thousand addicts in rural and urban areas throughout India; carried out extensive campaign in the desert regions of Rajasthan where drug abuse has eaten into the vitals of the society; helped to set up a viable Community Drug Rehabilitation Programme to prevent and cure drug abuse; used 'Camp approach' especially by bringing mobile camps to the doorsteps of the addicts and helping them through intense counselling and psychological treatment; established an 'after care centre' for drug addicts to strengthen their will power to abstain from future drug use; set up a vocational rehabilitation centre, where the detoxified addicts can either learn new crafts or sharpen their existing skills Rehabilitation of Disabled Children: Established, Sucheta Kriplani Shiksha Niketan, a unique residential Senior Secondary School to impart free and quality education to the physically disabled children in 1991; his dedicated efforts have resulted in the phenomenal expansion of the school's educational infrastructure, which now accommodates over 500 physically disabled boys and girls; the students of the school have made the country proud by their exemplary performance in mini sports organized by the Disability Sports, England by securing as many as ten and thirteen gold medals in the last two successive years, respectively; the President of India, the Vice-President of India and the Prime Minister of India have showered their blessings on these young capable children; under his guidance, this institution continues to scale ever-greater heights of excellence and creativity Aged Care: He has emphasized on strengthening of family values, and at the same time focused his attention on the welfare of the aged by providing them recreational, emotional, medical and financial support within the environs of the family thus benefitting thousands of old people in rural areas of Rajasthan Gaushala: Runs a Gaushala in which nearly 150 cows, ailing and uncared, are being sheltered and all facilities including fodder and medical aid are being provided Broad Institutional Contributions: Founded a number of trusts and societies dedicated to the cause of education, social service and environment all of which have contributed towards the upliftment of the rural people; Awarded two Gold Medals in National Games in 1969-70 at Barabati Studium, Cuttack, Odisha in 400 and 800 meters run; Cine Artist : acted in Oriya film Samarpan; participated in various national meets, sports and games; President, Odisha Basketball Association, 1986-2006; Vice-President, Basketball Federation of India; Founder President, Odisha Throw-ball Association since 1990; First President of Odisha Amateur Athletic Association

Visited, (i) Bangkok (Thailand), as a member of the National High level delegation to Bangkok to carry the Holy Cascade of Lord Buddha which was kept at Bangkok for public darshan on the occasion of Celebration of the 50th reign of the King of Thailand, (ii) Japan, as Chief De-Mission of Indian contigent to Asian Basketball championship at Kobe in 1991, (iii) Germany, to attend the ITB (Berlin) in 1997, and (iv) U.K., to attend the W.T.M. (London) in 1995 and 1996; Nepal, France, Holland, Brussels (Belgium), Amsterdam, (the Netherlands) , Hong Kong, Luxembourg, China and Dubai(U.A.E.)

Son of Jat Sikh parents born and brought up in Bhawanipatna town, Odisha in the midst of cross-cultural social life contributed by Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs; worked tirelessly for the welfare of the people particularly the poor and the marginalised; has been trying to bring prosperity to the agriculturists and to ensure that health and education services reach one and all; President, (i) Kalahandi College Students Union, 1971-72 and (ii) Lala Lajpat Rai Law College Students Union, 1973-74; Secretary, National Integration Samiti of Sambalpur University, 1972-73; Life Member, Bharat Krushak Samaaj; was President, District Congress Committee, Kalahandi, 1992-97; was Vice- President, Odisha State Youth Congress Committee, was Councillor (elected unopposed) of Bhawanipatna Municipality
